title: Mum spruiks breast milk for $20
text:
Mum places online ad in a bid to sell excess breast milk, saying users can “bulk up quickly” on it Natalie Keegan, The Sun March 8, 2017 12:09am 
A WOMAN is selling her excess breast milk online and suggests that bodybuilders might want to purchase the liquid “because of how quickly you can bulk on it”. 
The Sunshine Coast Daily in Queensland reported that the anonymous mum, from Australia, placed an advert on Craigslist, because she had an “oversupply” of breast milk. media_camera In her ad, the woman targeted bodybuilders, because of how quickly they can “bulk up” on the liquid (generic image). Picture: Thinkstock 
According to The Sun the woman wrote: “I know bodybuilders are supposed to go nuts for it because of how quickly you can bulk on it. 
“Anything else you want to do with it is totally up to you.” 
The woman added in her ad that “no other services” were being offered and the buyer would not be able to get the milk direct from the source. 
She continued: “I was thinking twenty bucks per bag (enough for me to buy more bags). 
“And if it’s of any interest, I am good looking, late 20s, big boobs (at the moment anyway).” 
But, while the milk may have benefits, buying it in this way would also come with a number of risks. media_camera The woman selling her breast milk said bodybuilders “go nuts” for the product (generic image). Picture: Thinkstock 
A study, published in British Medical Journal Researchers in 2015, found that breast milk sold on the internet was often contaminated with water, cow’s milk and high levels of bacteria. 
The research found that “black market” breast milk put the health of babies, and bodybuilders, at risk because it wasn’t screened in the same way as the milk sold internationally or donated locally to milk banks.
